column4: Summary of Key Crypto-Related Provisions
column6: Most Recent Action

column4: Expresses that it is the sense of the House of Representatives that the United States should support the expansion of domestic nuclear energy and advanced nuclear technology as a viable source of power in order to promote United States nuclear energy leadership and global energy independence, including by promoting advanced nuclear tech within digital assets, among other public policy areas.
column5: Reps. Chuck Fleischmann* (R-TN), Kat Cammack* (R-FL), Troy Nehls* (R-TX), Burgess Owens* (R-UT), Barry Moore* (R-AL), Randy Feenstra* (R-IA), Nancy Mace* (R-SC), Ben Cline* (R-VA), Randy Weber* (R-TX), Jefferson Van Drew (R-NJ), Buddy Carter (R-GA), Jay Obernolte (R-CA), Brandon Williams (R-NY), Doug LaMalfa (R-CA)
column6: Referred to the House Committees on Energy and Commerce and Armed Services - 2.14.23

column4: Directs the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network ("FinCEN") to establish and maintain modernized research and information sharing programs, including ensuring that FinCEN has the technology necessary to monitor crypto for potential money laundering and cyber and data breaches.
column6: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services - 1.17.23

column2: Preventing Opportunistic Returns on Trades and Futures by Officials, Leadership, and Individuals in Office Act or "PORTFOLIO Act"
column4:
Restricts certain federal employees--including Members of Congress, the President, and Vice President--from trading in certain investments, including "cryptocurrency or other digital asset," by requiring such employees to divest assets or place them in a blind trust.

Adds crypto to list of items that certain federal employees-- including Members of Congress and senior staff--must include in financial disclosure reports filed under the Ethics in Government Act of 1978.
column6: Referred to the House Oversight and Accountability, House Administration, and House Ways and Means Committees - 1.17.23

column4:
Requires the Department of the Treasury, in coordination with the Federal Reserve, to implement a strategy to ensure the dollar remains the primary gobal reserve currency.
 
Requires the Treasury to report on actions taken to implement this strategy, efforts made by foreign central banks to create an official digital currency, and evaluation of the role of the renminbi in international payments
column5: Reps. Jim Himes* (D-CT), Michael Lawler (R-NY), Monica De La Cruz (R-TX), Andy Barr (R-KY), Barry Moore (R-AL), William Timmons (R-SC), Byron Donalds (R-FL)
column6: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services - 1.26.23

column4: Prohibits money services businesses from engaging in any transactions involving a Chinese CBDC.
column5: Reps. French Hill (R-AR), Erin Houchin (R-IN), Debbie Lesko (R-AZ), Monica De La Cruz (R-TX), Andy Barr (R-KY), Barry Moore (R-AL)
column6: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services - 2.2.23

column4:
Prohibits any federal reserve bank from issuing a CBDC, or any product or service, directly to an individual. 

Prohibits the Fed from using any CBDC to implement monetary policy.

Requires the Fed to issue quarterly reports to Congress on the findings of any CBDC study or pilot program.
column5: Reps. French Hill* (R-AR), Warren Davidson* (R-OH), Andy Biggs* (R-AZ), Mike Flood* (R-NE), Byron Donalds* (R-FL), Pete Sessions* (R-TX), Barry Loudermilk* (R-GA), Young Kim* (R-CA), and Ralph Norman* (R-SC), Nancy Mace (R-SC), Scott Fitgerald (R-WI), Bryan Steil (R-WI), Don Bacon (R-NE), Mike Bost (R-IL), Jefferson Van Drew (R-NJ), August Pfluger (R-TX), Anna Paulina Luna (R-FL)
column6: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services - 2.21.23

column4: Amends ERISA to prohibit the Department of Labor from constraining or limiting the investment options that may be made available to 401(k) plan participants through self-directed brokerage windows.
column5: Rep. Warren Davidson* (R-OH), Michael Cloud* (R-TX, David Schweikert* (R-AZ), Tom Emmer* (R-MN), Young Kim* (R-CA)
column6: Referred to the House Committee on Education and Workforce - 2.24.23

column4:
Narrows definition of "broker" and "digital assets" for digital asset tax reporting requirements.

Limits information that must be reported for digital asset transfers between brokers and non-brokers to information that is voluntarily provided by the customer and held by the broker for a legitimate business purpose.

Directs the Treasury Secretary to study the impact of an IIJA provision that requires digital asset transactions of greater than $10,000 to be reported to the IRS (like cash transactions of greater than $10,000).
column5: Reps. Ritchie Torres* (D-NY), Warren Davidson* (R-OH), Ro Khanna* (D-CA), Tom Emmer* (R-MN), Eric Swalwell* (D-CA), David Schweikert* (R-AZ), Darren Soto* (D-FL), French Hill* (R-AR), Byron Donalds (R-FL)
column6: Referred to the Committee on Ways and Means and the Committee on Financial Services - 3.7.23

column4:
Directs the EPA to issue a rule requiring Bitcoin and crypto miners whose operations consume more than five megawatts of power to disclose emissions information.

Directs EPA and related agencies to study environmental impacts of Bitcoin and crypto mining in the U.S.
column6: Referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce - 3.8.23

column2: Regarding the importance of Proof-of-Work mining
column4: Expresses that it is the sense of the House of Represenatives that proof-of-work mining used for cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin are important to the United States' ability to achieve its energy and economic goals.
column6: Referred to the Committees on Energy and Commerce; Financial Services; Science, Space, & Technology - 3.21.23

column4: Clarifies that blockchain developers and service providers who do not take control of customers' digital assets--like, for example, miners and wallet software providers--are not subject to certain licensing and registration requirements applied to money transmitters and financial institutions.
column6: Passed House Financial Services Committee (29-21) - 7.26.23

column4: Establishes a working group to study and report to Congress on how new financial technologies, including digital assets, may be used for illicit uses and how to mitigate related risks.
column6: Passed House Committee on Financial Services (50-0) - 7.26.23

column4: Prohibits the Federal reserve and Secretary of the Treasury from issuing a CBDC without Congressional approval.
column6: Noticed for HFSC hearing on 9.20.23; not voted on, but incorporated in part into CBDC Anti-Surveillance State Act, which passed HFSC on 9.20.23 (27-20)

column4: Excludes "investment contract assets" from the definition of "security" under federal securities laws.  Investment contract assets are defined to include any digital asset that is sold or transferred pursuant to an investment contract, but that is not itself a security under the Securities Act of 1933.
column6: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services - 5.22.23

column4:
Provides an enhanced criminal penalty for knowingly or intentionally trafficking, or aiding or abetting the trafficking of, controlled substances via the dark web.

Directs the Attorney General to report to Congress on the use of virtual currencies in the distribution of opioids through illicit marketplaces on the dark web.
column6: Referred to House Committees on the Judiciary, E&C, and Financial Services - 5.22.23

column4: Establishes a working group at the Department of Defense to explore potential use cases for blockchain, smart contracts, and distributed ledger technology.
column6: Passed the House - 7.14.23

column4: Prohibits the Fed from running a CBDC pilot program without express authorization from Congress.
column5: 19 cosponsors listed here: https://tinyurl.com/CBDCnopilot. To be marked up by HFSC on 9.20.23.
column6: Referred to the House Financial Services Committee 5.25.23; Noticed for Hearing held on 9.14.23; but not voted on yet.

column2: Financion Innovation and Technology for the 21st Century Act ("FIT for the 21st Century Act")
column4:
Divides agency jurisdiction over digital asset market based on the token's functionality and decentralization. Asssets that are functional and decentralized are commodities subject to CFTC oversight.  The SEC retains jurisdiction over digital assets that are securities. 

Creates an exemption from traditional security registration requirements for digital asset issuers and requires them to comply with tailored disclosure requirements until the digital assets are certified as decentralized. 

Establishes registration and customer protection provisions for digital asset and digital commodity intermediaries like exchanges, brokers, and dealers.
column5: Reps. French Hill (R-AR), Dusty Johnson (R-SD), Tom Emmer (R-MN), Warren Davidson (R-OH)
column6:
Passed House Financial Services (35-15)(6 Ds) - 7.26.23;  

Passed House Ag (Voice Vote) - 7.27.23

column2: Clarity for Payment Stablecoins Act of 2023
column4: Provides pathways for insured depository instiutions and non-bank entities to issue payment stablecoins if they are approved by a Federal or state-based regulator and comply with certain Federal floor requirements relating to reserve assets, disclosures, capital, liquidity, and other items aimed at ensuring financial soundness and protecting consumers.
column6: Passed the House Financial Services Committee (34-16) - 7.27.23

column4: Protects the right to self-custody by prohibiting federal agencies from restricting a person’s ability to use crypto assets to buy goods and services, conduct transactions through a self-hosted wallet, or hold crypto assets in a self-hosted wallet.
column6: Passed House Financial Services Committee (29-21) - 7.27.23

column4: Requires Members of Congress to disclose financial interests in crypto and provides enhanced penalties for falsifying disclosures or filing late disclosures related to crypto asset holdings.
column6: Referred to the House Committee on Administration - 7.27.23

column4:
Prohibits the Fed from issuing a CBDC, offering prdocuts or services directly to an invdividual, or maintaining an accoun on behalf of an individual. 

Includes clarifying language prohibting the Fed from prohibiting any dollar-denominated currency that is open, permissionless, and private, and fully preserves the privacy protections of U.S. currency.

Prohibits the Fed from usign a CBDC or any simial digital asset to implement monetary policy.
column6: Reported favorably out of HFSC on 9.20.23 (27 Yes (all Rs) and 20 No (all Ds))

column2: "Electronic Currency And Secure Hardware Act" or "ECASH" Act
column4:
Directs Treasury—not the Fed—to develop and deploy an electronic version of the U.S. dollar, capable of offline peer-to-peer-transfers via hardware devices, called “e-cash.”

Requires Treaury to ensure e-cash replicates and preserves the privacy and anonymity-respecting properties and physical currency to the greatest extent possible 

E-cash could be used as legal tender and to pay taxes.
column5: Reps. Ayanaa Pressley* (D-MA), Rashida Tlaib* (D-MI), Jesus Garcia* (D-IL).
column6: Referred to the House Financial Services Committee - 9.12.23; Noticed for hearing on 9.14.23.

column2: Uniform Treatment of Custodial Assets Act
column4: Nullifies SEC Staff Accounting Bulleting 121 by prohibiting the SEC and federal banking regulators from requiring depository instutions to include digital assets held in custody for customers as liabilities on their financial statements or hold additional capital against digital assets held in custody for customers.
column5: Reps. Ritchie Torres* (D-NY), Wiley Nickel* (D-NC), French Hill* (R-AR), Andy Barr (R-KY)
column6: Referred to House Committee on Financial Services - 9.27.23

column2: Off-Chain Digital Commodity Transaction Reporting Act of 2023
column4:
Would require digital commodity swaps and digital commodity sales, whether occuring off-chain or on-chain, to be reported to registered repositories.

Repositories would have to register with the CFTC and comply with core principles (e.g., mitigate conflicts of interests), adhere to CFTC-prescribed data standards, and make data available to other federal regulators, including the SEC, DOJ, FSOC, and prudential regulators.
column6: Referred to the House Committees on Financial Services; Agriculture; and Ways and Menas - 9.27.23

column2: Adopting Cryptocurrency in Congress as an Exchange of Payment for Transactions Resolution or  "ACCEPT Resolution"
column4:
Requires the Architect of the Capitol, the Secretary of the Senate, and the Chief Administrative Officer of the House to contract with vendors who accept crypto as payment, unless there are more cost-effective and value-centered alternatives available. 

Encourages gift shops operating on the Capitol grounds to accept crypto as payment.
column6: Referred to the Committee on Rules and Administration - 1.25.23

column4: Amends ERISA to prohibit the Department of Labor from constraining or limiting the investment options that may be available to 401(k) plan participants through self-directed brokerage windows.
column5: Sens. Cynthia Lummis* (R-WY), Mike Braun* (R-IN), Rick Scott* (R-FL), Katie Britt* (R-AL), Ted Budd (R-NC), Ted Cruz (R-TX), Rand Paul (R-KY)
column6: Referred to the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions - 2.15.23

column4:
Directs the EPA to issue a rule requiring Bitcoin and crypto miners whose operations consume more than five megawatts of power to disclose emissions information.

Directs EPA and related agencies to study environmental impacts of Bitcoin and crypto mining in the U.S.
column5: Sens. Jeff Merkley* (D-OR), Bernard Sanders* (I-VT), Dianne Feinstein (D-CA)
column6: Referred to the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works - 3.6.23

column2: A bill to repeal the provisions of the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act that impose new information reporting requirements with respect to digital asset transfers
column4: Repeals section of the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act that imposed tax reporting requirements on brokers involved in the transfer of digital assets.
column6: Referred to the Senate Committee on Finance - 3.8.23

column4:
Establishes a task force of to study and report on improving digital identity, particularly with respect to digitizing existing forms of physical IDs, such as drivers licenses and birth certificates.  Report must include recommendations regarding leveraging distributed ledger technologies. 

Directs GAO to study and report on how digital identity might save the federal government money in the form of averted federal benefits fraud and identity theft.
column5:
Passed House Financial Services (35-15)(6 Ds) - 7.26.23;  

Passed House Ag (Voice Vote) - 7.27.23
column6: Voted favorably out of Senate Homeland Security and Government Affairs Committee - 3.29.23

column2: A bill to amend the Federal Reserve Act to prohibit Federal reserve banks from offering certain products or services directly to individuals
column4: Prohibits Federal reserve banks from issuing a retail CBDC, maintaining an account on behalf of an individual, or offering any other products or services directly to an individual.
column6: Referred to the Senate Banking Committee - 3.21.23

column4: Requires the Director of the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure  Secuity Agency to support federal efforts to bolster the security of open source software, coordinate with nonfederal entities to support the security of open source software, and publish a framework assessing risks and best practices regarding security of open source software.
column6: Reported out of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee with amendments and placed on Senate Legislative Calendar - 5.16.23

column2: No Central Bank Digital Currency Act or No CBDC Act
column4:
Prohibits the Federal Reserve and Secretary of the Treasury from issuing a CBDC directly to an individual or through a custodial intermediary, offer products or services directly to an individual, or maintain an account on behalf of an individual.  

Prohibits Federal reserve banks from holding digital currencies issued by the US Government as assets or liabilities and from  using such currencies to promote the Fed's monetary policy objectives.
column5: Senators Ted Cruz* (R-TX) and Mike Braun* (R-IN)
column6: Referred to the Senate Banking Committee - 3.23.23

column4: Establishes a working group to study and report to Congress on how new financial technologies, including digital assets, may be used for illicit uses and how to mitigate related risks.
column6: Referred to the Senate Banking Committee - 4.27.23

column2: Responsible Digital Asset Advertising Act of 2023
column4: Establishes marketing standards to prohibit false and misleading advertisements related to digital asset transactions and digital asset-related services.
column6: Referred to the Senate Banking Committee - 4.27.23

column2: Accountability for Cryptocurrency in El Salvador Act or "ACES Act"
column4:
Directs the Secretary of State to study and report on El Salvador's adoption of Bitcoin as legal tender, including an assessment of potential gaps in AML and the impact on the economy, rule of law, economic stability, the unbanked, and foreign relations.

Directs the Secretary of State to develop a plan to mitigate any risks to the U.S. financial system posed by El Salvador's
adoption of Bitcoin.
column6: Referred to the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations - 5.11.23

column4:
Provides an enhanced criminal penalty for knowingly or intentionally trafficking, or aiding or abetting the trafficking of, controlled substances via the dark web.

Directs the Attorney General to report to Congress on the use of virtual currencies in the distribution of opioids through illicit marketplaces on the dark web.
column6: Referred to the Senate Judiciary Committee - 5.18.23

column2: Prohibiting Foreign Adversary Interference in Cryptocurrency Markets Act
column4: Prohibits the CFTC from registering foreign entities based in China, Hong Kong, Macao, Cuba, Iran, North Korea, Russia, or Venezuela as digital commodity brokers, dealers, custodians, or trading facilities under the Commodity Exchange Act.
column6: Referred to the Senate Agriculture Committee - 6.7.23

column1: S. 2226 - Amdt. 1087 to Amdt.935 (NDAA Manager's Amdt.)
column4:
Directs Treasury to examine financial firm's effectiveness in identifying and reporting crypto use for money laundering and terrorist financing.

Directs Treasury to study and report to Congress on privacy enhancing technologies, including crypto asset mixers and tumblers, and the extent to which they are used by actors to engage in illicit finance.
column5: Senators Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY), Elizabeth Warren (D-MA), Roger Marshall (R-KS).
column6: Manager's amendment passed as part of NDAA (which passed Senate) - 7.27.23

column4:
Authorizes the CFTC to oversee crypto assets that are commodities and the SEC to overee crypto assets that are securities and administer periodic disclosure requirements for ancillary assets.  

Establishes numerous consumer protection rules, provides rules for depository instituitons to issue stablecoins, addresses various tax issues, and provides over $1 billion in funding for agencies to carry out the Act.
column6: Referred to the Senate Finance Committee - 7.12.23

column2: Crypto-Asset National Security Enhancement and Enforcement Act
column4:
Requires anyone controlling a DeFi trading protocol to comply with OFAC sanction regulations and BSA anti-money laundering requirements.

If nobody controls the DeFi trading protocol, anyone who has$25 million or more invested into the protocol may be penalized for sanctions or BSA violations instead.
column5: Senators Mike Rounds* (R-SD), Mark Warner* (D-VA), and Mitt Romney* (R-UT).
column6: Referred to the Senate Banking Committee - 7.18.23

column2: Digital Asset Anti-Money Laundering Act of 2023
column4: Requires anyone facilitating or providing services related to any crypto transaction to comply with the Bank Secrecy Act and other anti-money laundering requirements as imposed by FinCEN.
column5: Senators Roger Marshall (R-KS), Joe Manchin (D-WV), Lindsey Graham (R-SC)
column6: Referred to the Senate Banking Committee - 7.27.23

column2: Proving Reserves of Others' Funds ("PROOF") Act
column4:
Requires exchanges to obtain attestations from third-party auditors affirming that the exchange holds sufficient reserves to back customer assets.  

Generally prohibits exchanges from comminling customer funds with company funds and to hold customer assets in a manner that minimizes customer losses and avoids delays in customers accessing their assets.
column6: Referred to the Senate Banking Committee - 10.19.23
